commit_list.message: Correct 2 minutes in ms in docs

Correct spec for inputs

The input specs in the documentation online
(http://docs.basho.com/riak/latest/references/appendices/MapReduce-Implementation/)
and also in the tests, show that you can pass
inputs as a list of {{bucket, key}, AuxParams}.
The specs mistakenly had these written as
{bucket, key, auxparams}.

This has now been updated to allow dialyzer to
pass on correct usage.

Allow for javascript functions in spec

The spec has been adapted to be in line with the online
documentation found at
http://docs.basho.com/riak/latest/references/appendices/MapReduce-Implementation/

It now allows for both anonymous javascript functions,
as well as named built in functions, and anonymous functions
that are stored in riak.
Add readme, and push iOS changes
Add integration to PID controller
Files that I forgot to add to previous commit

Change signature for PID
Foundation for PIDController
Add file for PID controller
Initial Commit

Fixed yearly user churn

It was not correct, and would make it look like you got
a negative user count if you had a 100 user churn...

commit_list.message:
Use batch training mode.

Train in batch. Don't check intermediate
next word values, but compute them at the
end instead.
Also say "thanks" when the client says
it is done with a text :)
Find three best next words in O(n)

A lot of cosmetic text changes

Text is beautified for better presentation
Remove printf's used for debugging

Make predictions for sub sections of sentence

The predictor was to aggressive in giving up.
Now it works as anticipated. If it cannot find
a match for the beginning of the sentence, it
drops the first word an tries again.

Lowercase the keys for better matches

Keys were case sensitive. That might make sense in some
applications, but not in this where we only really want
a lot of matches :)
Now have a TCP listener that can train and predict
Add methods for training and text prediction
Add fold and to_list method to trie implementation
Change syntax from add to set

This is a clean commit of writewithme

Unfortunately this was a commit I needed to do,
in order to clean this repository of an incredibly
large database that was committed into it in the past.
I was unable to rebase in such a way to remove it from
the history.

Hopefully I will be able to come up with a better solution next time!

Updates the license owner

Whether having a license is necessary at all,
and what the license should be, are good questions.
I find it better to have a license than to have
no license, as explicitly adding one removes any
potential (and unecessary) source of confusion.

I chose Apache 2.0 since it is liberal, and easy
to deal with.

commit_list.message:
Allow complex gets, sets, deletes, and set_p

Allow gets where subelements of arrays
are searched for a particular pattern:

Given:

    {"cakes": [
      {"frosting":"white", "tastes":"good", ...},
      {"frosting":"red", "tastes":"good", ...},
      {"frosting":"blue", "tastes":"bad", ...}
    ]}

and the query:

    {"cakes", {"frosting", "white"}}

we should get:

    [{"frosting":"white", ...}].

Given the query:

    {"cakes", {"tastes":"good"}}

we should get

    [{"frosting":"white", "tastes":"good", ...},
     {"frosting":"red", "tastes":"good", ...}]

Allow setting and deleting complex values

When setting a value at a complex path it replaces the old value, and
adds a parameter to make sure the complex path is still valid:

    {"beaches": [
         {"sandy":true,
          "name":"Family beach"
       },{"sandy":false",
          "name":"Less friendly beach"
       }]
    }

    ej:set(
        {"beaches", {"sandy", true}},
        Beaches,
        {struct, [{<<"name">>, <<"Sandies">>}]}).

Returns

    {"beaches": [
         {"sandy":true,
          "name":"Sandies"
       },{"sandy":false",
          "name":"Less friendly beach"
       }]
    }

While

    ej:set(
        {"beaches", {"sandy", true}, "water_temperature"},
        Beaches,
        <<"Pretty Warm">>}).

Appends the property to the existing entry:

    {"beaches": [
         {"sandy":true,
          "name":"Family beach",
          "water_temperature":"Pretty Warm"
       },{"sandy":false",
          "name":"Less friendly beach"
       }]
    }

If there are multiple entries matching a complex query,
then all of them will be affected by the change.

Support for deleting one or more records using complex
queries is also supported.

A new method, set_p is now introduced, which behaves
much like the -p option for mkdir. Missing intermediate
nodes are created on demand.

Create new objects from scratch:

    > S = ej:set_p({"users", {"name", "sebastian"}, "location"}, {struct,[]}, <<"Germany">>).
    {struct,[{<<"users">>,
              [{struct,[{<<"location">>,<<"Germany">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"sebastian">>}]}]}]}

Append non existant values while using filtering

    > S1 = ej:set_p({"users", {"name", "sebastian"}, "company"}, S, <<"aircloak">>).
    {struct,[{<<"users">>,
              [{struct,[{<<"location">>,<<"Germany">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"sebastian">>},
                        {<<"company">>,<<"aircloak">>}]}]}]}

    > S2 = ej:set_p({"users", {"name", "seth"}, "company"}, S1, <<"opscode">>).
    {struct,[{<<"users">>,
              [{struct,[{<<"company">>,<<"opscode">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"seth">>}]},
               {struct,[{<<"location">>,<<"Germany">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"sebastian">>},
                        {<<"company">>,<<"aircloak">>}]}]}]}

Getting values through filters

    > ej:get({"users", {"name", "seth"}, "company"}, S2).
    [<<"opscode">>]

Or accessing values inside an array:

    > ej:get({"users", "company"}, S2).
    [<<"opscode">>,<<"aircloak">>]

    > ej:get({"users", {"name", "sebastian"}, "location"}, S2).
    [<<"Germany">>]

Whole subtrees of an object can also be replaced when using the filter:

    > S3 = ej:set_p({"users", {"name", "sebastian"}}, S2, ej:set_p({"location"}, {struct, []}, <<"Norway">>)).
    {struct,[{<<"users">>,
              [{struct,[{<<"location">>,<<"Norway">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"sebastian">>}]},
               {struct,[{<<"company">>,<<"opscode">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"seth">>}]}]}]}

commit_list.message:
Spec fix: batch_query/{3,4,5}

A batch query might return multiple errors,
or a combination of errors and results:

  pgsql_connection:batch_query("INSERT INTO missing VALUES ($1);", [[1],[2],[3]], C)
  > [
  >   {error,{pgsql_error,[{severity,<<"ERROR">>},
  >                        {code,<<"42P01">>},
  >                        {message,<<"relation \"missing\" does not exist">>},
  >                        {position,<<"13">>},
  >                        {file,<<"parse_relation.c">>},
  >                        {line,<<"984">>},
  >   {error,{pgsql_error,[{severity,<<"ERROR">>},
  >                        {code,<<"42P01">>},
  >                        {message,<<"relation \"missing\" does not exist">>},
  >                        {position,<<"13">>},
  >                        {file,<<"parse_relation.c">>},
  >                        {line,<<"984">>},
  >   {error,{pgsql_error,[{severity,<<"ERROR">>},
  >                        {code,<<"42P01">>},
  >                        {message,<<"relation \"missing\" does not exist">>},
  >                        {position,<<"13">>},
  >                        {file,<<"parse_relation.c">>},
  >                        {line,<<"984">>}
  > ]

Spec fix: simple_query can return multiple errors

simple_query/{2,3,4} can return both an error and result.

Examples:

  pgsql_connection:simple_query("CREATE TABLE a (n integer); CREATE TABLE a (n integer);", C).
  > [
  >   {error,{pgsql_error,[{severity,<<"ERROR">>},
  >                        {code,<<"42P07">>},
  >                        {message,<<"relation \"a\" already exists">>},
  >                        {file,<<"heap.c">>},
  >                        {line,<<"1047">>},
  >                        {routine,<<"heap_create_with_catalog">>}]}},
  >   {{create,table},[]}
  > ]

Adjust return type spec of simple_query/{1,2,3}

A simple query that performs multiple actions
result in a list of results. The current spec
definition does not reflect this.

An very artificial example would be:

  Sql = [
    "CREATE TABLE table1 (n integer);"
    "CREATE TABLE table2 (n integer);"
    "DROP TABLE table1;"
    "DROP TABLE table2;"
  ],
  pgsql_connection:simple_query(Sql, C)

Which returns:

  [
    {{drop,table},[]},
    {{drop,table},[]},
    {{create,table},[]},
    {{create,table},[]}
  ]

This does not correspond to the return type of result_tuple(),
but rather [result_tuple()], like is used in batch_query/{3,4,5}
Add test for microsecond time inserts

Supports inserting times at microsecond resolution

Postgres supports timestamps and times with up
to microsecond resolution:
http://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.1/static/datatype-datetime.html

pgsql already supports reading times with sub-second
resolution, and this commit adds support for inserting
times with up to microsecond resolution.

Update erlang doc to reflect supported Erlang rels

The set of releses is now taken from the sources
specified in the erlang chef cookbook.

commit_list.message:
[SignpostDemo] Use concurrent queues for jitter

Jitter measurements are now executed on concurrent
queues, instead of serial queues like before.
This seems to give better performance, and anecdotal
evidence seem to show that the iOS clients also
report somewhat smaller jitter as a result as well.

The is a synchronized block that is executed in the
UDP receive block. This is a contention point in the
jitter measurement. The measurement itself is concluded
outside this block of code as the first thing upon
receiving the UDP message. Now that concurrent queues
are used, the jitter calcualtions can all be concluded
before the thread has to wait for exclusive access to
the user data variable. Gain :)
commit_list.repo_description: Code for the Signpost demo applications

commit_list.message:
[SignpostDemo] Updated jitter UDP protocol

Changed the UDP protocol to make it easier to code
against for non Cocoa devices:

The message format expected of the packages are:
'HOSTNAME\r\nTIMESTAMP\r\nJITTER'

The hostname is the id of the host. Same as is used
in the initial handshake.

The timestamp is the time in seconds since 1970.
The value used in the cocoa clients is a NSTimeInterval.
The following is from its documentation:

  NSTimeInterval is always specified in seconds;
  it yields sub-millisecond precision over a range
  of 10,000 years.

The jitter is also a double specifying jitter in ms.
For the sending party, the jitter should be the jitter
the client sees the in the messages received by the other
party. The server will reply with the jitter seen for
the jitter UDP probes from that particular client.

commit_list.message:
[SignpostDemo] Protocol change

The protocol has now changed to make it easier to
write an android app to work against it.

(All messages, with the exception of the
 raw data messages, are terminated by \r\n)

PING - LATENCY Sequence is now:

---------- start of sequence ----------
C->S PING
S->C Num bytes the data will/shall contain
C->S Latency as seen by the client
S->C ----data----
C->S Downstream bandwidth in mbit * 1000
S->C Latency as seen by the server
C->S ----data----
S->C Upstream bandwidth in mbit * 1000
---------- end of sequence ----------

commit_list.message:
[bug] Jitter calculation would stop

The jitter calculation would update for 12 seconds and then stop.
The reason was that after the first 60 jitter measurements, no new
ones would be added to the jitter database. Or more correctly, they
would get added, but immediately removed again :p

Now I remove the oldest measurement, instead of the one that was just added.

Fixes #1

commit_list.message: Adds placeholder index page

Allow complex gets, sets, deletes, and set_p

Allow gets where subelements of arrays
are searched for a particular pattern:

Given:

    {"cakes": [
      {"frosting":"white", "tastes":"good", ...},
      {"frosting":"red", "tastes":"good", ...},
      {"frosting":"blue", "tastes":"bad", ...}
    ]}

and the query:

    {"cakes", {"frosting", "white"}}

we should get:

    [{"frosting":"white", ...}].

Given the query:

    {"cakes", {"tastes":"good"}}

we should get

    [{"frosting":"white", "tastes":"good", ...},
     {"frosting":"red", "tastes":"good", ...}]

Allow setting and deleting complex values

When setting a value at a complex path it replaces the old value, and
adds a parameter to make sure the complex path is still valid:

    {"beaches": [
         {"sandy":true,
          "name":"Family beach"
       },{"sandy":false",
          "name":"Less friendly beach"
       }]
    }

    ej:set(
        {"beaches", {"sandy", true}},
        Beaches,
        {struct, [{<<"name">>, <<"Sandies">>}]}).

Returns

    {"beaches": [
         {"sandy":true,
          "name":"Sandies"
       },{"sandy":false",
          "name":"Less friendly beach"
       }]
    }

While

    ej:set(
        {"beaches", {"sandy", true}, "water_temperature"},
        Beaches,
        <<"Pretty Warm">>}).

Appends the property to the existing entry:

    {"beaches": [
         {"sandy":true,
          "name":"Family beach",
          "water_temperature":"Pretty Warm"
       },{"sandy":false",
          "name":"Less friendly beach"
       }]
    }

If there are multiple entries matching a complex query,
then all of them will be affected by the change.

Support for deleting one or more records using complex
queries is also supported.

A new method, set_p is now introduced, which behaves
much like the -p option for mkdir. Missing intermediate
nodes are created on demand.

Create new objects from scratch:

    > S = ej:set_p({"users", {"name", "sebastian"}, "location"}, {struct,[]}, <<"Germany">>).
    {struct,[{<<"users">>,
              [{struct,[{<<"location">>,<<"Germany">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"sebastian">>}]}]}]}

Append non existant values while using filtering

    > S1 = ej:set_p({"users", {"name", "sebastian"}, "company"}, S, <<"aircloak">>).
    {struct,[{<<"users">>,
              [{struct,[{<<"location">>,<<"Germany">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"sebastian">>},
                        {<<"company">>,<<"aircloak">>}]}]}]}

    > S2 = ej:set_p({"users", {"name", "seth"}, "company"}, S1, <<"opscode">>).
    {struct,[{<<"users">>,
              [{struct,[{<<"company">>,<<"opscode">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"seth">>}]},
               {struct,[{<<"location">>,<<"Germany">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"sebastian">>},
                        {<<"company">>,<<"aircloak">>}]}]}]}

Getting values through filters

    > ej:get({"users", {"name", "seth"}, "company"}, S2).
    [<<"opscode">>]

Or accessing values inside an array:

    > ej:get({"users", "company"}, S2).
    [<<"opscode">>,<<"aircloak">>]

    > ej:get({"users", {"name", "sebastian"}, "location"}, S2).
    [<<"Germany">>]

Whole subtrees of an object can also be replaced when using the filter:

    > S3 = ej:set_p({"users", {"name", "sebastian"}}, S2, ej:set_p({"location"}, {struct, []}, <<"Norway">>)).
    {struct,[{<<"users">>,
              [{struct,[{<<"location">>,<<"Norway">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"sebastian">>}]},
               {struct,[{<<"company">>,<<"opscode">>},
                        {<<"name">>,<<"seth">>}]}]}]}

commit_list.message:
Correct return type spec for run_query/1

Thanks @nifoc.

Closes #7
Remove compiled protocol buffer

Bring back checks for R15

At aircloak we are no longer using R15,
but since this is open source, we should
keep backward compatibilty with R15 a while
longer

Update to Lager 2.0 and rebar build with R16

This is a modernization commit more than anything.
It brings the versions of the dependencies up
to a more recent state.
Remove R14 as a test target
Add rebar to repo

Adds `all` as a build dependency of `test`

Running a `make test` from a clean repository
failed because of missing dependencies.
Doing a `make all` first gets the dependencies.

Bugfix: Atoms -> String conversion is done

The protocol buffer definition expects string values,
and I was passing in atoms. The values that are expected
to be strings, are now converted if they are not.
Bumps protobuf version + adds changelog
Readme: Adds thanks to

Merge pull request #3 from timshadel/master

Make rebar deps firewall-friendly
Adds to .gitignore
Add thanks to readme

Merge pull request #2 from Aircloak/proto_fix

Proto fix
Closes #1

Changes query to pb_query in proto

`query` is a reserved keyword in erlang,
and caused builds to fail on R16B
Add R16B to travis build

Remove test function

I had left in a function that was only
meant to be there while testing the initial
version of the riemann client.
It is not in any way useful for any
application that uses the client, so
I have removed it.
Since it was an exported function this
does change the public API, but I hope this
does not cause any problems.
[README] change riemann example host name
Add build status image to readme
Add travis support
Add info about how to configure riemann
Use git tag for version number
Add apache license 2.0
Add dialyzer make task
Add readme
Add support for running queries
Add end to end test plus state messages

Book keeping cleanups

Removed the ebin files from the repo.
Also made lager start with app.
Additionally added a description to the app.
Rename the server state to `state`

Rename messages in proto to avoid name conflicts

The names used in the original protocol buffer
definition were very generic. The `query` message
for example collided with the erlang reserved keyword
of the same name.

`event` and `state` and  `attribute` were also too generic.
The names have now all been name spaced with riemann to
avoid confusion and conflicts.

Initial version that can send data to riemann

This version supports sending events to riemann.
It also reconnects to the riemann server if it has been down.
Initial commit

Redirect after off, so it doesn't retrigger

If the app is loaded on the phone in the browser,
then the browser might redo the GET request to
show the page if it has been evicted from memory.
That would retrigger another Away event, which is
not desired. Now I am redireting to a fresh page
which can safely be reloaded without any side effects

Light where I am, not where I am not

The current version does:

- turn the light to the max in rooms I am in
- turn the light to the max in neihgbouring rooms,
  in case I am going in there. If I am not, then
  the light is slowly dimmed over a period of 5 minutes
- all rooms I am not in, and that are not neighbouring
  the room I am in, have the lights turned completely off

commit_list.message:
[frost] Add more proper JSON-RPC message types

Better handling of message types on client sides,
and now there is also a response type so clients
can send back results of JSON-RPC requests.

[frost] basic rpc and tactics mechanism in place

Upon resolving a name, all tactics are now executed in parallel.
At the moment there is only a silly direct connection tactic
that doesn't do anything at all useful. What it does demonstrate
though is that you can now send JSON-RPC requests and notifications
between the server and the client.

TODO: Handle replies to requests sensibly.
      This requires that information about the sender
      is also part of the RPC request, since we are not
      using a traditional bidirectional channel, but instead
      sending data grams.
      It should also take into account the correct ID, and
      match it against a request ID, such that the requesting
      entity gets the response.
[frost] minor refactor of nodes

[frost] add script to query local server

Script that queries the local DNS server.
It gets the server name from the configuration file.
A small utility so one doesn't have to remember which
order the dst.src are in.

call as:
  cd script
  ./query_local_dns.sh <name>

[frost] Use record for node data

Use a record for node data so it can be extended
with additional data, as needed.

Additionally a Sp module is added which contains
Signpost specific types.

[frost] remove testing method from signal

There was a legacy testing method in the signal
module that was no longer used.
It has been removed.

[tactic_engine] add original design plan

This plan will get updated as we move along.
It is the original design plan sent out per email.
The current implementation will be substantially
more simplistic

[frost] refactoring node related code

Moved node information from the signalling module
out to a separate nodes module to get a cleaner
separation of responsibility.

This is the first step in making a nodes module
that can hold more state needed by the tactic engine.
Iodine tactic changes that were not picked up

Try to run tactics

The engine now takes a sequence of tactics and
tries to execute them by sending messages through
a signalling channel.

This is a very naive approach at the moment, and there
is a lot of duplicated working being done.

Add signalling channel

Add signalling channel as its own module.
Also rename the function used to check if
tactics are stackable or not.
Changes in older code.

Only choose tactics providing something new

When building up the execution three of possible tactic
combinations, only choose tactics that provide at least
one property not already provided by a previous tactic.
Also deduplicate the list of properties provided as listed
in the final list of tactics combinations.

Add new dummy engine

This is engine number one trillion.
What it currently does, is create a static
list of all the possible link combinations
we can create. Then later on, when we need
a link of a certain characteristic, we can
filter the list to find the possible
combos that produce at least the required
characteristics.

Initial attempt at tactics that return futures

Mainly a code push to show some code to
Andrius for further cooperative development.

Output *.annot files

This aids development as function types can be
seen in Vim

Fixed a boolean true|false error

A flag to determine if a bidirectional tunnel
already was set up was flipped the wrong way...

Trying to establish more sensible connections

Now when trying to set up a connection between two nodes
A and B, the following will be attempted:

If no bidirectional channel exists between A and B:
Open channel:
- A to B with B as relay
- B to A with A as relay
- A to B with any other node as relay
- B to A with any other node as relay

If a bidirectional channel has already been established,
then it will not bother trying both A to B and B to A.

Trying to establish more sensible connections

Now when trying to set up a connection between two nodes
A and B, the following will be attempted:

If no bidirectional channel exists between A and B:
Open channel:
- A to B with B as relay
- B to A with A as relay
- A to B with any other node as relay
- B to A with any other node as relay

If a bidirectional channel has already been established,
then it will not bother trying both A to B and B to A.

Updated tactic engine

The tactic engine need to use reactive programming of some sort.

This is just a quick test to see what sort of connections it
can setup.

Beginnings of an OCaml tactic engine

The tactic engine tries to establish
an end to end path by executing tactics
that provide at least of the requirements
of the link.

This is very much an initial skeleton,
and has to be fleshed out and fixed. :)

Changes to assumptions.

Stuff to remember for the future, in case it is needed.

Fixed a bug, plus add r-script

Didn't take into account the number of signpost
devices a user had.

Added a script to generate basic graphs in r so
that the data can be inspected.

A new approach to getting the signpost cost

I believe this new approach is more sane.
Assumptions are stated in the file.

Now has a notion of signpost users

Each signpost user has a set of devices.
When a signpost user makes a signpost request
this has some overhead for the other signpost devices
as well.

When a friend contacts your signpost nodes, that
causes some syncronisation overhead within your
signpost network too.

Friend access follows a power law distribution.

Now, imagine we have three nodes A, B and C.
A and C both see B, but not each other.
Now, if A wants to resolve something on node C,

Therefore we now have an ugly broadcast, where
everyone broadcasts whatever they get to everyone...
O(n^2) in the case where everyone is connected.
Not nice, but will work for our tests.

Add logging to the system

For better visibility into what the system does over time, I have
added a logging class. It logs most actions that are done. The logs
are quite verbose, but should help debug multi signpost setups, if
that is needed later.

The log format is as follows (also documented in the logger class):

  # # From the communication manager
  # - new_signpost_connection: signpost_name
  #     When a connection has been made with a remote signpost in the same
  #     domain.
  # - request_remote_signposts: signpost_name
  #     When the list of signposts known by a remote signpost in the same
  #     domain is requested
  # - return_list_of_signposts: signpost_name
  #     When a signpost returns the list of signposts it knows about
  # - request_remote_truths: signpost_name
  #     When a signpost requests the truths known by a remote signpost
  # - send_truth: signpost_name, *truth
  #     When a truth is passed on to a remote signpost. Constains the full
  #     truth data... this might be an issue in case sensitive data is
  #     passed... Should be changed before the system is put into production
  # - signpost_connection_closed: signpost_name
  #     When the connection to a remote signpost is terminated
  # - resolve_truth_remotely: signpost_name, what, user_info
  #     When a signpost requests a remote signpost to resolve a truth. Log on
  #     the signpost that requests the truth to be resolved.
  # - resolve_for_remote: signpost_name, what, user_info
  #     When a truth is to be resolved locally for a remote signpost
  # - return_list_of_truths: signpost_name
  #     When a signpost returns a list of the truths it knows to a remote
  #     signpost
  # - initiate_connection_to_signpost: signpost_name
  #     When a signpost initiates a connection to a remote signpost
  # - adding_remote_truth: signpost_name, *truth
  #     When a truth from a remote signpost is received and added to the local
  #     truth table. The signpost name is the name of the signpost that sent
  #     the truth.
  #
  # # From the tactic thread pool
  # - create_tactic_instance: tactic_name
  #     When an instance of a tactic is created.
  # - serve_truth_request: tactic_name, what, user_info
  #     When a tactic instance is used to resolve a truth
  #
  # # From the tactic scripts
  # - add_truth: tactic_name, truth, user_info, ttl
  #     When a tactic adds a new truth to the solver
  # - pass_truth_to_tactic: tactic_name, truth
  #     When a tactic passes on a truth from the solver to the tactic script
  # - add_observer: tactic_name, requirement
  #     When a tactic requests to become an observer of a truth value
  # - add_need: tactic_name, requirement
  #     When a tactic requests to become an observer of a truth

Truths can be evaluated remotely

A tactic can request a truth to be evaluated on another signpost.

To test this in the interactive shell, run:

ruby runner_tactic_solver.rb (will be "server")
ruby runner_tactic_solver.rb (will be "client-1")
ruby runner_tactic_solver.rb (will be "client-2")

then, if you run the following on client-1
r ip_for_domain@www.kle.io server
the tactic will be run in the server tactic solver.
The result will then be pushed to both client-1
and client-2. Both of which have daemons observing
truths of types ip_for_domain@... which will spawn
and run the pingable_ip_for_domain@... tactic :)

When a signpost connects to other signposts, it requests
a lists of its truths. This way it bootstraps more rapidly,
and the nodes get, hopefully, a more or less consistent view
of the world.

Add support for background daemons

background daemons:
Daemons can be declared in the tactics config.yml file.
Unlike tactic scripts, they cannot statically define
requirements. Daemons can act very much like normal tactics,
only that they should not restart.

value observers:
tactics and daemons can become truth observers.
That is: they are forwarded truths are they are
created or updated, but do not cause a truth to
be created if it doesn't already exist.

helper:
the tactic helper is now upadted to support both
tactics and daemons.
The helper also takes into account the dependencies
of individual user supplied blocks of code, and ensures
the blocks are only reevaluated when its dependencies
have been updated.

Implement recycling tactics and tactic thread pool

This was a necessary change to get around the
tactics solvers abysmal performance.
Tactic instances now live in a tactic thread pool
which lazily expands as required.
Instead of terminating, a tactic should now instead
recycle itself (all green and sustainable!).
It does so by sending the tactic solver a

    {"recycle":true}

message, and resetting itself to its initial state.

[README] make up to date

The readme is updated to show that unix sockets are now used
for communication, rather than STDIO.

The example on how to use the ruby helper class was also
somewhat expanded.

[NOT BACKWARDS COMPATIBLE] Comm using unix sockets

This commit is not backwards compatible!
The tactics are now communicating with the
tactics scripts using unix sockets rather than stdio.
The unix socket is passed to the tactic script as the
first and only argument.

The tactics now use EventMachine connections rather
than threads. This should be cleaner, and hopefully better.

Performance is still abysmal.

Migrate the tactic_solver to routing_info

The tactic_solver is now called routing_info. The new tactic_solver is
instead intended to be a dynamic data flow construct that sets up
connections on the fly and memorised stuff it needs to do so.

Add TTLs to link evaluations

TTLs are added to link evaluation (strategy instances). Nodes remove
links as they time out. The node responsible for the link reevaluates
the strategy before the link is invalidated. To ensure that a link
isn't continuously removed and then readied, the node responsible for
the link takes into account how long it took to previously evaluate the
link when deciding when to reevaluate it.

Evaluate tactics in parallel, and add heartbeat

The tactic solvers do now no longer block while evaluating the tactics.
Additionally there has been added a heartbeat between the signposts
that ensures that information about old links are removed as signposts
die

Tactic solver evaluates tactics

The tactic solver now evaluates tactics when new devices are added.
The resulting data are stored as "links" and distributed to the other
tactic solving signpost nodes.

separate runner file.

All nodes then rendevouz and find each other.

Comment on message marshalling, and added session id

Added a comment stating that, while the message passing syntax is
really verbose in the draft, a real implementation could use something
like protobufs to limit the number of bytes on the wire.

I also added a session_id part to the connection confirmation message.
This session is must then somehow be passed from a client to a device
upon connecting. It can also be used by the personal signpost to tell a
device that an open connection should be terminated because of changes
in policy.

Initial draft for how what components are part of the signpost system

The draft contains details on the role played by: * DNS * Signpost
client * The personal signpost * The central signpost  It also sketches
out ideas for what sort of communication could find place between the
signpost client and the personal signpost.  Feel free to edit as you
please!

The direct connection tactic now works on
my local box. The nodes that are trying to
connect send UDP messages to one another, and

them repeatedly.

Connections store state and originating tactic

Reworked RPC module

The RPC module did not comply with JSON-RPC, and had
grown somewhat out of control.
In this commit is it trimmed down to support JSON-RPC
as specified on http://json-rpc.org/wiki/specification.
The parser is very strict and unforgiving. If messages
do not conform with the standard, or if there are
ambiguities, then they will get rejected.

Tactic specific RPCs are now also encoded as standard
JSON-RPCs, and the OpenVPN connection module and the
OpenVPN Manager have been updated accordingly.

This commit also adds functionality that allows
the signpost client setup script autodetect
the server settings, so a user does not have to
manually type them.

Clients public IPs are served to DNS

Upon signing up, the server and client
figure out which IP's the server can connect to,
and as a result, which IP's are assumed to be
publicly accessible.

These IPs are stored, and returned as the result
of DNS requests, rather than the signalling channel
IP, which was previously returned, but should not
be used for anything but signalling.

This squashed commit contains a whole range of
commits from both Haris and Sebastian.

One bug fix, and some printouts for clarity

Added some printouts to get better insight into how the system works.

Stores and returns public ip-addresses

Upon receiving a hello message from a client,
the server sends an RPC queryring the client for its
ip-addresses. The server then tries to send a UDP
packet to each of the addresses, and collectively with
the client discovers which addresses are publicly
available and which ones are not.
The ones that are publicly available are then stored in
the connections table, and returned alongside other
tunnels as the answer to DNS requests.

Fix token syntax error

The client splits the token and the IP by '-', so when
using - in the token itself, it got confused, and didn't split
the data correctly. As a result it would never return any valid
public IPs

This tactic doesn't work very well at the moment.
It still highlights how tactcs can be written,
and how the system currently operates.

It has each of the nodes get a list of the ips it sees itself having.
Then each of the nodes try to send datagrams to the other nodes ips.
Each node then returns the IPs it received datagrams from...

Needs more testing, and the results returned by the tactic are
currently only printed to the stdout, rather than added to the nodes
themselves.
